div.head: The Eygptian Gazette
THE RESULTS OF THE BATTLE.
div.p: The only news of the Russian Army today is that attempts have been made to hinder the progress of the pursuers by destroying the bridges at Kai-Yueu, which is a station north of Tieling on the line to Kharbin, and was evacuated by the Russians on Saturday. We are in ignorance as to whether a decision has been taken to halt only at Kbarbin, which is about 200 miles north of Kai Yuen, or to keep up a show of fighting with the victorious enemy at every point of vantage. But it is clear that no serious resistance can he offered, for the other mighty host is an army only in name, a mob with, or in many cases without, rifles, (duns, stores, ammunition, transport, all are gone, and with them the morale of the army, the last shred of confidence in its leaders. The demoralisation which it took two months of the retreat from Moscow to accomplish, has been effected in and fortnight of battle. The narratives which are now arriving, though they only tell what one knew must be happening, represent the whole district to the north of Mukden as an inferno of human suffering ; no medical service in the .world could cope with the mass of wounded that have been flung upon the Russian surgeons ; antiseptics, anesthetics, all that modern science has devised for the mitigation of suffer, ing, are lost or exhausted, and amid horrors indescribable, and confusion inconceivable, has come the end of the great Manchurian Army. Yet for the moment Pharaoh has hardened his heart The tales of horror and unparalleled disaster have had no effect upon the Tsar, except to strengthen his determination. At the Imperial Council held last week it was resolved to continue the war to the last gasp, to call out fresh Reserves, and to mobilise another 400,000 men. In any country hut Russia it would he impossible to treat such madness in earnest It took over a year to bring up from Russia the army which has just undergone so frightful a defeat; yet the rail way was in full working order, during the earlier part of the war the confidence of the nation and the soldiery was unbroken, and an unbroken force guarded the railhead. To collect a fresh army and transport it to Men-ohuria is, probably, beyond the capacity of the Russian Empire, however much the truth may be disguised from its ruler; and even it such an army were to be organised, the inferiority of the Russians in the battlefield has been only too painfully manifested. Yet^"granting all this, we believe that for the present, at any rate, there is small likelihood of pacific counsels being listened to. The Tsar has always believed implicitly in the ultimate triumph of Holy Russia, and his obstinate disposition, backed by his evil genius in the shape of Admiral Alexeieff, shows no signs of yielding. You may break an autocrat, but you cannot bead him. The Government, more over, have only too good a reason to dread the return of the beaten army ; the tales which the disbanded soldiery would have to tell must add fuel to the flames of revolution that already are gathering head through every portion of the Empire. We can understand that a man so utterly unacquainted with the realities of war as the Tsar has shown himself may point to the vast untapped reserves of men in Russia, and to the nucleus of an army still in Manchuria, and may declare that in his opinion the war is only just begun. Nevertheless, there are signs that at the latest Council of War the Tsar was made conscious of the gross decepitious of which he has been the victim, and of the crisis to which ambition has brought him. There is yet another card, however, which is being played by the war party. Kodjest-veuskys squadrons are still intact, and by this time, alter their practice in drill and in maneuvers, are a really formidable fighting force. The stories of their unseaworthiness may be put aside ; ships can be cleansed and scoured in still water without the necessity of being docked. Still less is there any foundation for the idea that the Baltic Fleet will be recalled. Rodjestveusky is a man of determination, and orders are imperative, to seek out the foe now that there is no Port Arthur to be relieved, and deal a blow which may, at. any rate, save the Russian naval honor and give the Government at home something with which to allay public despair. A drawn engagement, or even a lost battle in which the Japanese suffered material damage, would be the first step to peace. We do not wish to be understood as thinking that anything which Rodjestveusky may achieve can alter the balance in the Far East He has come much too late, and even supposing, what we do not think either probable or possible, that be inflicted a decisive defeat of Togo, could he now do any. thing to interfere with the Japanese army> in Manohuria 1 Oyama by this time is well nigh independent of sea transport, and he has, apart from his own magazines, the whole to the Chinese province to draw supplies from Besides this the completion of the Chemulpo Pusan Railway has reduced the length of sea that has to be traversed to a matter of 50 miles, while the tonification of the Tsu-sima islands would render an effective block and most difficult even to a more numerous and more efficient fleet. Rodjestveusky is not a real factor in the operations of the war, but his failure or success may make a groat difference in the willingness of the Tsar to accept terms of peace. There is still another consideration even more potent than the obstinacy of a military despot, and that is finance. It is clear that Russian resources and Russian credit are strained to breaking .point. The gold reserve may not all be exhausted, but the patience of French investors and German financiers is wearing out The Russia debt coupons continue to be paid, but only by fresh and reckless borrowings, and the time mast be near at hand when the stream will run dry. Then, if not before then, will peace becoming inevitable,

div.head:
GERMANY AND MOROCCO.
KAISEU'S LATEST SENSATION. HIS MAJESTY TO VISIT TANGIER

div.p: The announcement that the Emperor William will shortly visit Tangier is causing a sensation, owing as it does simultaneously with the reports that the French mission to Fez has completely failed. It is believed that the Saltan has appealed to Germany against the French pretensions ; hence the Emperor's visit (Reuter.)

The semi-official "Norddeutsche Allgcmein fitting" reaffirms that Germany's interests in Morocco are purely economic. Hitherto there has been no reason to suppose that the Sultan intended entering into engagements which would curtail his independence or pre- vent the granting of equal commercial facilities to all. In this question, the interests of the world's trade have to be considered. (Reuter.)
While the strike of the railwaymen on the Trans-baikal line has ceased, the telegraphists are now out. (Reuter.)
The Reichstag has passed the Bill increasing the Army. (Havas)
The Royal yacht, with the Queen of England on board, heading to Lisbon, has had to take refuge here owing to the storm! (Havas)
Mr. Hammerstein is dead. (Havas.)

div.head: The Pilgrimage.
div.p: The S.S. "Mariout" arrived at Suez yesterday with 1,012 Egyptian pilgrims.

div.head: A Council of Ministers
div.p: will be held at Ahdecti Palace, under the presidency of H.H. the Khedive, on Thursday next.

div.head: The Plague.
div.p: No case of plague was reported in any part of Egypt last week. The country is now, happily, free of the disease.

div.head: "Alexandrie en Baisse,"
div.p: M. George Ralli's latest "revue," will be produced for the first time at the Alhambra this evening.

div.head: R. Berks.
div.p: The sergeants of the Royal Berks Regiment are giving a small dance in their mess-room at Mustapha tomorrow evening.

div.head: Alexandria Stock Brokers Association.
div.p: The election of the president and committee, which should have taken place yesterday after- noon, was postponed owing to want of a quorum.'

div.head: Al Azhar.
div.p: The Grand. Sheikh of A1 Az r University, Said el Behclawi, has resigned reasons of health, and has been replaced Sheikh Abdel Rahman el Ghcrbini.

div.head: K.S.C.
div.p: We should like to remind our readers that tomorrow's Skye Meeting is the event of the winter racing season. There are numerous entries in the seven races and excellent sport is promised.

div.head: New Lunatic Asylum.
div.p: The "Mokattam" states that the Sanitary Department has decided to build' a lunatic asylum in Lower Egypt, probably at Alexandria. The new asylun will accommodate 600 patients.

div.head: Mena Motor Accident.
div.p: According to the "Lewa," Prince Mohamed, Aly, whose motor recently ran over and killed a native boy at Nan, has expressed his regrets to the boy's father, and given her 10 feddans of land as compensation.

div.head: Suez Canal.
div.p: 27 vessals passed through the Canal on the lO haml 17th init. Of these, 17 were British, 5 German, 2 Dutch, 1 French, 1 Russian, 1 Italian. The receipts for the two day.- were frs. 714,859 34, making the total from the latest 6,114,252.64.

div.head: Helouan Representative Institutions.
div.p: The advocates of representative institutions in Egypt should ponder over the suppression of the Helouan Municipal Commission, which ceased to exist on the 31st ulto. Its functions have been handed over to the Ministry of Public Works.

div.head:
THE WAR.
RUSSIAN COUNTER ATTACKS. KROPATKINS NEW COMMAND

div.p: Oyama reports ^that the Russian counterattacks on Kai-Yiien have been repulsed. The Russians are burning the bridges to the south of Kni-Yunn. A number of Russian guns have been found buried at Mukden. (Reuter.)
General Kuropatkin has been appointed to the command of the First Army in Manchuria. (Havas.)

div.head: Interesting to Tourists.
div.p: A special train will leave Cairo to morrow morning at 9.45 for Alexandria, to which carriages will be attached for the convenience of passengers for the Khedivial Mail steamer "Iswailia," sailing at 4 p.m. for Athens, Smyrna, aud Constantinople. These special carriages will convey passengers alongside the vessel on the company's quay iu the Arsenal basin.

div.head: Beau-Rivage Hotel.
div.p: This charming Ramleh hotel has reopened fur the summer season. Mrs. Luigi Steiuschueider has transferred the direction of the hotel to Mr. G. Ruuckewiu, the well-known manager of the Anglo-American Company's Nile steamer Victoria." The business will be continued on the same lines as have made the hotel so successful in the past. A large number of applications fur rooms have already been received from tourists, who desire to pass' a short time in the lovely neighbourhood of Ramleh, before proceeding to face the cold Weather in Europe.

div.head: What Next!
div.p: So many companies have been recently started iu Egypt, aud with such varied objects, that people can with difficulty keep the run of them. Still, our confrere the "Fhute d'Aiexandrie" heed not have invented a new company,, vide its financial article of yesterday, which announces "l'he Alexandria Central Hallway Company," having - amongst other objects the very singular one oi "Cexportation d immeubles." When everybody is laud grabbing it is very unkind to talk of exporting any. Perhaps Sir W. Gars tin was not so far wrong in stopping laud sales if that is what will happen.

div.head: St. Mary's School, Cairo.
div.p: The entertainment given by the girl pupils of St. Mary's School, Cairo, yesterday was very successful, the room being quite crowded. Lord and Lady Cromer, the Bishop in Jerusalem and the East, Dean Butcher, etc., were present, and the performance was greatly enjoyed. There was really very little nervousness shown by the actors in the two little operettas performed, and the singiug was true and in time. Miss A. Sarruf and the Misses Nunr performed well, and were well supported by the other members of the caste. Altogether a very pleasant little entertainment, at the conclusion of which Lord Cromer expressed his pleasure and satisfaction with all lie had seen and heard, aud congratulated the Rev. and Mrs. Odeli on the excellent results of their teaching.

div.head: St. Patricks' Day on S.S. "Arabic."
div.p: The members of the S. S. Arabic's athletic club were "at home" to the Royal Army Medi- cal Corps and their friends on St Patrick's Day. Alter a cricket match at Ras-el-Tiu between the teams of the ship and K.A.M.C. athletic club, the members of the R.A.M.C. and their friends went ou board the "Arabic" and sat down to a splendid cold collation, to which every one did justice. During the even- ing a very enjoyable smoking concert was held. During the concert the company were honored with a visit from the captain ahd some of his friends, who seemed to highly enjoy the concert. Speeches were made by the presidents of the respective teams, hoping they would soon huvea chance of meeting again. Pressure on our space alone prevents us from publishing the excellent programme gone through.

div.head: NATIONAL BANK OF EGYPT, MEETING OF SHAREHOLDERS.
div.p: The fifth ordinary general meeting of the shareholders, the National Bank of Egypt was held in Cairo yesterday afternoon, when the directors submitted the balance sheet and profit and loss account for the year ending the 31st December, 1904. These show a gross profit of £397,737. 7. 8, of which £154,630. 3. 3, derived from special investments, are exceptional profits. Deducting rebate of interest, £13,656. 5. 3, and the current expenses, £58,692 7. 2, there remains a net profit of £325,38$. 15.3. The following distribution is hid down by the statutes of the Bank : 4 % to the capital, or 8s. per share, £80,000, 10 % of t tenet profit to the reserve fund, £32,538.17.6, 10 % to the directors, £21,284.19.9, leaving a balance of £191,564.18, to which must be added the balance carried forward last year, viz., 23,882.10.1, making a total of £215,447.8.1. The directors recommended the payment of a dividend of an additional 6s. per share, which will absorb £60,000 and leave £155,447.8.1. They further recommended that a sum ot £125,000, to be taken from the exceptional profits referred to above, be carried to an extraordinary reserve fund to be employed specially for equalising future dividends, and that £30,447.8.1 be carried forward to profit any loss new account. Each share will thus be entitled to 14s, equivalent to 7 per cent, on the capital.
The following is the text of the speech of the chairman (Sir Elwiu Palmer) :

Gentlemen,I am glad to be able to lay before you smother satisfactory balance-sheet Tho year 1904 has been a very prosperous one for the bank, as the figures in the profit and loses account show. Irrespective of the profits derived from the sale to part of our holding of agricultural Bank shares, we are able to pro- pose a dividend at the rate of 7% as against 6%, the dividend paid for 1903. in addition to the sum of £32,538, which, in accordance with the statutes, is added to the ordinary reserve fund, we propose to carry £125,000 to the extraordinary reserve fund, to which we have also added the premium, less expenses of issue, on the 50,000 shares issued in 1904. If you approve of the £125,000 mentioned above being carried to reserve, we shall then show a total reserve amounting to £862,000, which would be about doubled if we took into account the present prices of the Agricultural Bank shares u e still hold, instead of showing them at their nominal value. The . work of the bank in all its branches has considerably increased. Our deposits, which at the end of 1903 amounted to £1,670,000, wore at the end of 1904 £2,131,000. Since the close of the year we have opened branches iu the chief town of each province to cope with the Government work ; the surplus Government funds being now paid over to us and on our branches by the different Government Departments by cheque. Tho opening of these branches involves no doubt extra expenditure, but I hope that in course of time they will be of considerable profit to the bank. Another very satisfactory feature of the year is the increase in the circulation of notes. The average circulation during tho year 1904 was L.E.454,000, against L E.218,000 in 1903. On the 31st December, 19u4, there were in circulation L.E.5^8,000, while on the 51st December, 1903. the circulation was only L. E. $82,000. Since tho close of the year the circuation has exceeded L.E. 800,000. It is evident that the notes are becoming much more popu- lar and it will not be long, I hope, before we reach a circulation of a million. The increase of work generally has involved higher salaries and a larger staff. Much credit is due to the whole staff for the efficient way in which they performed their duties. In the course of the year Mr. Abdy, who has rendered considerable service to the bank, resigned his appointment of Sub Governor and we were lucky in obtain- ing the services of Mr. Dickson, who was mana- ger of the Ionian Bank at Athens, to take his place. Mr Rowlatt, whose services are invaluable, has .become the senior Sub-Governor.

div.head: CAIRO STOCKBROKERS AND ALLOTMENT.
div.p: The Committee of the Cairo Stockbrokers Association met yesterday evening to consider a question which has lately attained con- siderable importance. The resolution proposed by a group of stockbrokers was that:
' A partir de ce jour, aucuno affaire ne pnurra 6tre traitde à la Bourse sur lesnouvelles dmisrions availt que la rdpartition de celles-ci n'ait dtd faite. "
The Committee after a long discussion unanimously approved the following resolu- tion :

"Pour les socidtds constitudessous le rdgime des lois dtrangdres et faisaut des dmissions en Ejypte, ancune transaction ne sera perniise à la Corbeille taut que Pon ne connattra pas les rdsultats do la rdpartition, sauf decision con traire de Fassemblde gdndrale des agents de change. "

div.head: EGYPTIAN OPTIONS.
div.p: There seems to be some internal dispute over the latest Egyptian companythe Au- gusta Syndicate, which is apparently attempt- ing to place privately the shares of another concern, Egyptian Options, Limited. At all events, a correspondent points out, an in- spection of the Augusta register showed that it was entirely a one man company, Mr. John Waddington holding the whole of the five thousand shares except those in the hands of the signatories to the articles of association. According to this account also, Mr. Wadding- ton proposes to take 1,750 Founders' Shares in Egyptian Options (Limited),

div.head: TANTAH ASSIZE COURT. FIRST SITTING.
div.p: The first sitting of the new Assize Court was held here yesterday morning uuder the presidency of Yebia Bey Ibrahim, assisted by Judges Willmore and Mohrez Bey. The Judicial Adviser an lived the day before and attended the court.

Among the cases brought up for hearing was one of attempted murder, for which the accused were sentenced to 'five years' penal servitude. The sentence has been some- what criticised by some lawyers as being very severe, but there is a prevailing idea that such severity will do good in decreasing crime.
The sitting will deal with eighteen cases until Thursday, when further instructions are expected.

The court room yesterday was filled with lawyers and notables. In the three cases heard I observed that the sentences wero given always after consultationa matter that inspired considerable confidence among those present

div.head: THE KHEDIVE.
div.p: Yesterday, the Khedive gave audience at Abdeen to M. de la Boulinifere, who presented M. Paul Oziol; and to Sir E. Zohrab Pasha, Mohamed Ali Bey, Moudir of the Fayoum, Mesciaca Bey, Adib Bey, and Talamas Bey, Col. the Hon. M. Talbot Pasha, Sir Rudolph von Slatin Pasha, Yacoub Pasha Artin, Prince Haider, Mr. F. H. Cook, and Amin Rehan Effendi.
At 3 p.m. his Highness gave audience to Col. FitzGeorge and M. Wassif Alician.

div.head: THE WRECK OF THE "CAIRO."
div.p: Messrs. Almagia were to have made an attempt to refloat the S.S. "Cairo" to-day, but bad to postpone the operation on account of the bad weather which is prevailing.

div.head: NOTES FROM PORT SAID.
div.p: About 40 Russian officers from Port Arthur landed at Port Said to day from the P. and 0. "Mongolia," having transhipped at Colombo from the P. and 0. "Chusan." They will proceed to Odessa via Alexandria.
The Earl and Countess of Carnarvon, Viscountess Helmsley, and the Earl of Erne passengers by the "Mongolia" from Colombo to Marseilles.
There were also on board 14 distressed British subjects who embarked at Freemantle from the wrecked Orient Pacific liner "Orizaba."

div.head: EGYPTIAN ARMY.
div.p: The Khedive has been most graciously pleased to confer the 2nd Class Mejidieh on E! Lewa Lord E.H. Cecil Pasha, D.S.O., Sudan Government.

Captain H. D Beamish, the Leicestershire Regiment, having reported his arrival in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Ajmy, with the rank of Biinbashi. This officer is posted to the 12th Sudanese.

Lieutenant S. B. B. Dyer, D.S.O., 2nd Life Guard, having reported his arrival in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, with the rank of Bim- bashi This officer is posted to the Camel Corps.

2nd Lieutenant J. Stuart-Wortley, the Cameronians (Scottish Rifles), having reported his arrival in Egypt from England, has been taken on the strength of the Egyptian Army, with the rank of Bimbashi. This officer is posted to the 11th Sudanese.

div.head: ARMENIAN COMMUNITY
div.p: The Deputative Assembly of the Armenian community, at its last session, under the presidency of Boghos Pasha Nubar, on the 17th inst, deliberated upon the proposed building to a national school, and after a lengthy dis- cussion decided on erecting the new school, not within the precincts of the church, as was at first intended, but in a fashionable quarter of the city Three of the members were deputed to secure a plot of ground of about 3,000 metres in a suitable position. The new building is to contain three different sections, for boys, girls, and a Kindergartern.

Before dispersing, the chairman, Boghos Pasha N Ubar, expressed his astonishment at the fact that iu the whole of Egypt not a single institution for the commercial training of the European youth existed, and expressed his intention of erecting, at his own expense, a Commercial High School for the Armenian youth in Cairo. All present congratulated his Excellency on this munificent offer and the session closed.
We understand that Boghos Pasha Nubar has set aside a sum of 1,000,000 fre. for this school, and has already secured the site for its erection.

div.head: NOVELLI'S LAST APPEARANCE.
div.p: The great Italian actor N0yelli gave his last performance at the Zizinia yesterday evening before a full house. The well-known drama Vistruttoria was producted, Novelli being splendid and the rest of the company support- ing him well He was repeatedly called before the curtain and received an ovation which should encourage him to pay us a return visit His monologue at the end of the performance was greatly appreciated.

div.head: EGYPT'S MINES. STOCK EXCHANGE BOOM.
div.p: Egyptians are very strong on the London Stock Exchange. The "Financier" of March 13 remarks :

Whether the present revival in Egyptians is the harbinger of a coming boom is beyond our ken, but we can vouch for the quiet but persistent way in which shares are being aK sorbed both on Cairo and home account This morning, for instance, it was the only section with any vitality in it Practically all the leading market counters met with supported, despite a steady downpour of rain, dealings were kept up to a comparatively late hour in the Streeta circumstance which clearly points to the fact that some, at any rate, are nervous of being caught "short," as was the case when Nile Valleys had their sharp spurt just before the close of last year. Some exception seems to have been taken to the proposal of the Urarus Company to raise more capital in order to increase th stamping power,seeing that the old shares still have a liability of 5s. attaching to them. The market as a whole, however, was disposed to regard the scheme with favor, it being argued that the capitalisation can well stand a slight increase, and thus the company would then be left with a substantial amount of uncalled capital for future contingencies. It is, however, highly desirable that development work should he pushed ahead with all speed, as the present 9,000 tons of ore available will not go far even on the present basis of opera- tions, to say nothing of the additional stamp- ing power on the tapis.
The "Financial Times" of March 14 remarks:

Chief interest centered on Egyptians in the Mining markets again to-day. A very fair amount of business is reported to have been transacted in these descriptions, and the result was that the improvement in values made further progress. Market men are looking for continued activity in this section, in connection with which there are greater potentialities than with either the Kaffir or Westralian departments, the Egyptian gold mining industry being in its infancy. It is the "glorious uncer- tainty" that encourages speculation, as has been more than once remarked, and it is thought that Egyptians, by reason of their unknown possibilities, and in view of the movement in prices that has occurred during the last few days,are likely to receive increased public attention in the near future. There was some profit takingly House speculators during the latter part of to-day's session, and in some cases closing quotations were under the best, but the movements on balance in this section were all in favor of holders. The chief changes were in North Niles and Block "Es," the former rising 5/32 to 2 15/32 and the latter 3/32 further to 1 27/32. Sudan Mining Syndi cates, which rose £ on Saturday, put on 3/16 to-day, and "Mummies" closed Is. higher at 198. 6d. after touching 19s. atone time. A small advance was again scored by Um Rus, at which mine, a cable now reports, crushing was commenced on the 6th instant The shares of a new concern, "Egyptian Options," were introduced on the market to-day, and after considerable dealing the price closed l£-lf.
The " Financier " of the same date also states:

Having repeatedly remarked on the absur- dity of the supposition that any resumption of activity in these markets must necessarily take root in the Circus, we may perhaps be pardoned a mild "chortle" at the seeming correctness of our view. As on Saturday, Egyptians have again practically monopolised attention in these markets. Precisely what has brought this particular sphere of speculation into favor may be best explained by the wonderful pro- gress the country is making, the growing po- tentialities of the mining industry, the cheap- ness of money, and last, but not least, the want of a speculative arena wherein the inves- for and the speculator alike are afforded an excellent opportunity of stepping in on what practically speaking, the ground floor. It is the natural course of things that the tide of prosperity which at present permeates the gilt- edged markets should gradually turn into more speculative channels. Egyptians have the ad- vantage of starting with a dean slate. Thanks to the careful administration of Lord Cromer, the "wild-cat" dement is non-existent All the companies are floated on a sound commercial basis, and whatever the investor or the specu- lator dabbles in, he may be sure of a fair run for his money. It need not invasion surprise, therefore, that, with business waking up in all directions, the Egyptian Mining market should be receiving serious consideration. At any rate, the volume of business transacted in this sec- tion to day, compared with that in other directions, justifies the precedence we have given it Dealers again report a substantial demand from Cairo, and, in addition to the business executed on home amount, there was the further redaction in the hear posi- tion to take into account. Several venturesome spirits, tempted by the lengthy stagnation of the market, have allowed themselves to go jtort of certain shares, with the result that Khey now stand a fair chance of being "caught," and are thus helping the movement along by their efforts to take ©over. It seems invidious to single out any share for special comment, as the rise is so general.

div.head: PERSONAL AND SOCIAL
div.p: It is stated that on their return to London the Duke and Duchess of Connaught will take up their residence at Chrenoe House. The wedding of Princess Margaret and Prince Gnstavns Adolphus of Sweden will be the great event of the season. It will, we understand, take place at the Chapel Royal, St. James', where the Prince and Prinese of Wales were married.
Lady Cromer will distribute the prizes at the Government school athletic sports on Thurs- day. Lady Cromer will not be " at home " on that day.

Amongst the many distinguished visitors at present staying at the Savoy Hotel are the ex-Empress Eugenie and suite, includiug Princese Bonaparte de la Moskowa, Mile de Basano, Comte de Clary, Comte Primoli and M. Franceschini Pietri, the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, the Marquis di Rudini, Col. Sir Augustus FitzGeorge, Sir Ernest Cassel, Lord and Lady Armstrong, Lord and Lady Carnarvon, Mr. William Waldorf Astor, Lady Leucha Warner, etc.
Sir John Denison Pender, vice-chairman of the Eastern Telegraph Company, desires ua to state that he has not any connection with any mining concern in Egypt or elsewhere.
Ghazi Mukhtar Pabbi, Imperial Ottoman High Commissioner, in leaving for Europe about the end of next month.

Sir Ernest Cassel entertained a party to dinner yesterday evening at the Savoy Restaurant, the guests including the Duke and Duchess of Devonshire, Mazloum Pasha, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer, Count and Countess Antoine de Zogheb, De Martino Pasha and Mme de Martino, Fabrioius Pasha and Mme Fabricius, Col. Sparkee, Major and the Hon. Mrs. Bourke, Hon. J. W. Biddle, Sir Gerald FitzGerald, Capt MacLean, Major and Mrs. Johnstone, Mr. and Mrs. George Boyle, Miss Boyle, Col. and Mrs. J. K. Watson, Mrs. and MUe de Zogheb, Capt Kennedy, Dr. MacCallan, Lady Rogers, Birch Pasha, Mr. Castelli.

Saturday's small dance at the Savoy was attended with the usual success. The restaurant was full up both for dinner and supper. Amongst those giving large dinner parties were Mr. and Mrs. Bell with a party of 14, including Col. and Mrs. Burn, Major Palmer, Mr. William Waldorf Astor, Col. Watson, Sir Elwin and Lady Palmer, and Mi. Forbes Leith. Mr. and Mrs. Perkins had a party of 10, including the Misses Harley, Capt the Hon. A. F. Stanley, Sir William Garstin, and Mr. Rnmboldt M. and Mme Em. Zervudachi had a party of 6, including Mr. and Mrs. Graham and Mr. and Mrs. Hnnter Pasha. M. and Mme Witonk de Modem had a party of 7, including Mr. and the Misses Zakrewsky and Mme de Maskena Mme de Weerth entertained Sir Horace and Lady Pinching, Mr. Morgan, and Baron von Bassus.

We also noticed in the restaurant the ex- Empress Eugenie with her suite, including Princess Bonaparte de la Mosoowa, Comte Primoli, Comte Clary, Mue de Bassano, and Mr. Pietri. Others noticed were Mr. and Mrs. George Boyle, Miss Royle and Capt McLean, Mr. Vincent Corbet, Mrs. and Miss Smallman and party, Mrs. and Miss Leverich and party, Dr. and Mrs. Armstrong and party, Mr. Mansfield Hunter and party.

Adly Pasha Yeghen entertained a party to dinner in one of the private dining-rooms of the Savoy Hotel yesterday evening. The guests were Prince Ahmed Fouad Pasha, M. and Mme de Villebois, MUee de Villebois, Mohamed Abani Pasha, Harari Pasha and Mme Harari, M. and Mme Adolphe Cattaui,Sir Edward and Lady Z >hrab, M. and Mme Tamvaco, Fouad Pasha, Birch Pasha, M., Mme and MUe Gennadis,MAnd Mme Trehaki,De Martino Pasha and Mme De Martino, Mme Aghion, M. and Mme Joseph Cattani, the Marquis de Sorogna, MUe Caradja, Khairy Bey, Ibrahim Tewfik Pasha, Mme A. Lozzato, Mr. Heller, Abdel Rahim Sabri Bey, Ibrahim Naghib Pasha.
Adly Pasha Yeghen is giving another big diuner this evening at the Savoy.
Dr. and Mrs. Rncker-Jenisch have left Cairo on an excursion as far as Assouan.
H.M. King George of Greece has conferred the Order of the Saviour (3rd class) on Mr. E. Benachi, president of the Hellenic community of Alexandria.

Among the latest arrivals at the Eastern Exchange Hotel, Port Said, are Mr. H. Langridge, Miss J. Davies, Miss Springhett, Mr. R. Clark, Mr. and Mrs. Bain, Misses Bain, Misses Chaplin, Mr. G. 0. Williams, Mr. J. Campbell, Mr. A. J. Millard, Mr. C. Charles, Mr. C. B. Scott, Mr. W. B. Logan, General Davidson Smith, Miss Smith, Miss Milne, Miss Handley, Mr. K. H. Tabet, Mr. and Mrs. 0. B. Butler, Mr. K. Janaka, Mr. J. J. Fischer* Mr. T. L. Washington, Mr. E. Land.

div.head: STOCKS AND SHARES
div.p: Furnished by Reid & Bernard 10, St. Marks Buildings, Alexandria, and Sharia Kasr-el-Nil, Cairo, who undertake the sale and purchase of Stocks and Shares, on the local Bourse and also on the London Stock Exchange.

div.head: GENERAL BOOTH'S VISIT TO JERUSALEM. THE JULIAN'S FEARS. A REMARKABLE PROCLAMATION
div.p: General Booth, the "Father" and founder of the Salvation Army, arrived here in the afternoon of the 8th inst. on his first visit to the Holy Land, accompanied by Commissioner and col, Major Cox, and other officers of his staff, having been preceded a few days previously by Colonel Lawley, his private secretary, and Colonel Roussel, Under-Secretary for "Foreign Affairs," to make all necessary arrangements in connection with the General's visit to the Holy City. It appears, however, that before leaving England the Turkish Embassy in Loudon was communicated with in order that they might obtain the Forte's sanction for holding an open-air public meeting at Jerusalem, and that they received assurances that their application would be attended to. The suspicions of the .Ottoman Government, however, were aroused as to the real object to a meeting in Jerusalem, considering the title of the organization, and more especially their motto "Blood and Fire," which sounds to a Turk not unlike that of a revolutionary body. Orders were consequently sent to the Governor of Jerusalem not to allow General Booth and his followers to hold or address meetings in public and to take all precautions to prevent Ottoman subjects attending any of their meetings. These unexpected injunctions caused disappointment to the aged leader and his party, but the difficulty put in their way was overcome by au arrangement with the American Missionary Alliance to use their "tabernacle" as a gathering-place, and accordingly a series of meetings were held in that hall. On each occasion the place was densely crowded with people of all sects and denominations to hear General Booth's addresses, which were translated into the vernacular Arabic. The inhabitants were much impressed by the earnestness and noble qualities of the great preacher, who was listened to with deep interest throughout, the braided too lies and jerseys attracting at the same tune up little attention. On Saturday, 11th, the principal European residents, including the Consular Body and the heads of the Christian religious missions and communities, were invited to meet General Booth at the Hotel Hughes. Most to those invited attended, and alter the usual introductions the General spoke of the romance of his work, and of the shaping of that great fabric which is known to day as the Salvation Army, relating how 35 years ago he was denounced,persecuted, and ridiculed as an eccentric fanatic, but that despite all opposition he had resolved to movement the films of the great cities of the world, and with perseverance had worked on rusting in God and the Gospel to give him victory sooner or later. How he toiled from one inside to another, regardless of all criticism id opposition, until he laid a solid foundation, and be felt proud in saying that now the rich and the poor, the king and the peasant, the Jhrfs'ian and outcast, all recognized that be had introduced a new and effective agency to battle with misery, misfortune, vice, and crime through Christian charity, to which work he dedicated the whole of his life. The speech in general was a review of the organization. General Booth enumerated the branches of the work, and the number of the institutions and homes founded in 49 different countries of the world, giving details and figures os to their inmates, and the enormous masses benefiting by those charities. He referred with a feeling of gratitude and emotion to his visit to Jerusalem as one of the happiest events to his life. It was, he said, a ..Teat privilege bestowed upon him by his Master to spare him until now to fulfill a life- me's dream. At the close of his speech the general received a splendid ovation from the audience, and the British Consul proposed a vote of thanks to General Booth for the interesting address, to which he briefly rm s ponded. Despite his 76 years, General Booth is a hale and potent figure, vibrant with the energy which testifies to an earnest purpose within. It is impossible to view his patriarchal presence without an instinctive deference to the degree

"Comrades and friends, belonging to every section of Christian and philanthropic work, look at the waste howling wilderness of unbelief and wretchedness only vaguely pictur ed here. "Look at it. Oh 1 look with the eyes and feelings with which the Great Christ viewed it, when He climbed this sacred Hill, and with if greatness which alone can set a man on such i pedestal of esteem and obedience as he occupies. Though not gifted with eloquence or suavity of speech he possesses a homely genuineness, a friendly naïveté which is over in head, and a sympathy a broad as his purpose is direct General Booth visited all the important historical places in and around Jerusalem, and the most noteworthy event in connection with his visit is that of bis reading and signing the following proclamation on Gordon's Calvary, which was done privately in thou presence of his suite and a few friends. During the signing of the document the Salvation Army banner was unfurled over the head of the General. He leaves Jerusalem to-day for Jafla and will embark to morrow lor Fort Said on his way to Australia for the third time. The following is the text of General Booth's proclamation :— "On behalf of the outcasts, a call from Jerusalem to all who name the name of Christ throughout the world. " The dream of a lifetime is fulfilled. I am in Jerusalem, at the very heart of scenes for aver hallowed by my Lord and Master's life, buffering, and death. i " I have visited Bethlehem and in imagination listened to the Seraphic anthems with which the Angels ushered Him unto the world. I have walked the streets of the city once trodden by His sacred feet I have stood on the brow of Olivet, and gazed in deepest sympathy on the pitying tears wept over the Godforsaken people who were about to shed his blood. "I have looked on other places made memorable by their connection with the tragic incidents of His earthly career. For just he, they have shown me the Pool of Siloam, the village of Bethany, while in the distance they have pointed out to me Nazareth, Jericho, and the Jordan. They have showtime the reputed sites on which the Temple stood ; the place of the Master's betrayal; the Palace of Herod ; and the Judgment Hall where Pilate condemned lira to die. And as I thought upon that Hall saw once wore the Crown of Thomas, the Mocking Robe, the Mimic Reed, the cruel scourging, while down through the ages I seemed to hear again the frantic cries of the mob, 'Crucify Him, Crucify Him.' "With indescribable feelings I have prayed in Gethsemane Garden, ascended the Hill called 'Calvary,' and worshipped with reverent awe on the very ground where the Cross of Shame was erected on which my Lord purchased by lis broken heart sufficient Sovereign saving grace to meet the needs of the wild human race. I have looked into the empty sepulcher where cold in the arms /of death my Savior lay. Then passing on I have wonderingly beheld the mount from whose summit He ascended triumphant over death aDd Hell to plead with the Father the cause of the world He had so gloriously redeemed. And as my eyes rested on those sacred scenes, again and again has the question suggested itself, "Why all this suffering, why did He die, and for what did He die t" And then I have remembered the answer which came from His own blessed lips. Luke XIX. 10. "That was His commission received from the Father, and as His Father commissioned Him, so He commissioned His Disciples. And if we are His disciples our task is the same, namely: the Salvation of the Lost. "About the length and breadth of that commission there can be no mistake. Beyond question it comprehended then and comprehended to-day the conditional deliverance of every one from sin, irrespective to nationality, character, aDd condition.— "By tho Grace of God Ho tasted for every man," "Whosoever oomph to Him He will in nowise cast out," "He was and is still the Savior of the world." "Judging from the state of the world to-day, has not the unbeliever some ground for pronouncing the Mission of Christ a failure I "Notwithstanding all oar proud boasting respecting the advancement of the World, could this outcast section be much more unlike the kingdom of Heaven He came to establish, or more closely resemble the kingdom of Hell 1 "Look at the brutal, selfish, senseless, inhuman wars by which the poorer classes are the greater sufferers. "Look at the chronic state of starvation, in which millions slowly waste and bitterly wail until delivered from their misery of the pauper grave. "Look at the countless array of drunkards held in the iron chains of demoralizing appetite. Think of their desolate wives, children and homes, their rapid return to the jaws of death, their.exclusion from Heaven and their doom in Hell. " Look at the hideous slavery involved in the shameless harlotry abounding in the entries of Christianity, with all the debasing results that fell in its brain. "look at the melancholy multitude of criminals shut behind prison bars, for whose regeneration, for this world or the next, little or no intelligent effort is made. "Look at the gay, frivolous crowds abounding everywhere, who in the paltriest pursuits waste the sacred opportunities given them to bless their people and prepare to meet their God."

div.head: Egyptian Delta Light Railways Co., Limited.
div.p: Connections made with the most important trains of the State Railway in the Provinces of Behera, Gharbieh, Dakahlieh Charkieh and Galioubieh.Through service for goods between all stations of the Company andover 100 principal stations of the State Railway in Upper and Lower Egypt. Goods may also be through-booked from or to any station on Helouan Railway. The Company has 70 stations opened for public Telegraph Service in conjunction with all offices of the Government Telegraph Department.For time tables, tariffs and information apply to the offices at Cairo, Alexandria Damanhour, Tantah or Zagazig. 21416 20-01.1905
